ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I really loved taking this class - I feel like I levelled up my chinese greatly by reading texts written for a chinese audience rather than textbook style passages.
I learned about Chinese film and short written works, and had a lot of opportunities to practice speaking and analyzing works in Chinese.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Ao Laoshi is a major strength - she is such a wonderful teacher even at 9.25am; sometimes there are crunch periods when a presentation is due alongside homework. The texts also take mea. very longtime to read. I think it would be helpful if there were a way to actually learn more of the vocab.

The class times are well spent and provide a great place to practice speaking. The films and essays that are chosen are quite interesting and enjoyable, and  spark interesting discussions in class. I wish that there were more smaller homework assignments through each chapter to get more familiar with the material.

This course's biggest strength was its content. The movies and stories that we studied were truly interesting and enjoyable, and led to fascinating class discussions.

The only weakness would be the organization of the course, with a semester schedule that changed quite a bit throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Some of the movies and stories are enjoyable to read. The discussions and topic of conversations are very interesting e.g gay rights, generation gaps
Yes! It was fantastic for both learning the language and culture.

I would definitely recommend this course. It is very enjoyable and a great place to practice Chinese. You certainly get out of it what you put in to it, so if you really want to learn more and practice advanced Chinese this course provides a lot of opportunities to do that, but if you would rather just use this as an opportunity to maintain your Chinese skills, this course does not force you to do too much work.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student studying Chinese. It is a fascinating class full of interesting conversation which teaches a lot about Chinese history and culture in an interesting way.
yes! a lot less "busy" workload than 130/140 but still a great way to improve chinese.
